blocks.text: During all the years, the Wax Museum has been on the air, what some eight, nine years, certain programs have attracted the attention of the audience more than others. But one thing is certain, the Montessori technique as against that of child development or approaches to education concerning the preschool child. The series of programs on the station has attracted far, far more attention, discussion, controversy than any series a single program during the past 10 years or so. And so, this morning you might call not so much confrontation, because obviously there is no one approach to the education of the preschool child. But this morning will be a gathering of two schools of thought. Dr. Urban Fleege, who was the vice president of DePaul University, and one of the leading exponents in our city of the Montessori school technique, and Hannah MacLaren, who was a teacher of the Ancona school society on the south side that engages in the technique known as Montessori is- Maria Montessori. Whereas on the other side we have Dr. Ner Littner, the Institute of Psychoanalysis and Fay Bauling who is now a guest lecturer at the Chicago Teachers College in nursery school education, representing the non-Montessori approach or what might be called child development. And since the last program or the last several programs involving both Montessori proponents and the non-Montessori advocates, there's been a great deal of audience reactions. When will the two meet, and the twain indeed have met and are meeting today. So, Dr. Fleege I know you represent Montessori, and I know, too, you have been listening to the programs, challenging it. I suppose the question immediately is conceptions, misconceptions, understandings, misunderstandings. The floor is yours, sir.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, Studs, I must admit that I- it was impossible for me to catch all of your program the last time in which our- two of the members around the, the table here this morning were discussing and rather raising questions I presume about this Montessori approach. I would first of all like to say that I wouldn't like to pose as a proponent but rather as one whose life time has been spent in child development and experimenting with it. And to my way of thinking this represents so many of the developments in modern research that in fact I find no other particular system of approaching the child that seems to involve and recognize the findings of research. Recent research. And hence we have become interested in experimenting in the application of these. About four years ago we helped found this Alcuin Montessori School out in Oak Park, and then the U.S. Office of Education became interested and they asked- They came out to visit it a number of times and have given us a little grant to help evaluate and follow these children and compare them with others, and this is what the in the pr- We are now in the process of doing that. From what I did hear of the discussion, and I'm sure all of these questions are raised with the best of good will. I rather suspect that some of them were based maybe on inadequate experience with the approach, and I would think largely misconceptions and maybe misunderstandings. Because I am sure that we, we should be in agreement on some of the basic principles that we know about how young children develop and the necessity of acknowledging individual differences and the advantage of presenting children with learning exercises that are geared to their readiness levels and so on. And so, I'm looking forward I'm sure as much as any of the listeners are to the opportunity for an exchange of opinions this morning, and I would rather suspect that toward the end we will be more in agreement than in disagreement. Unless of course we somehow or other get jockied into a position of drawing conclusions from maybe one or the other experience rather than an adequate consideration of the total application of the program.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Dr. Fleege, Urban, suppose we then pursue this further and perhaps enter the area of specifics who would you were ab--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I, I would like to--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Fay Bauling, you were about to say something--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: [laugh]
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I, I would like to say that I- this is exactly what I wanted to do this morning that the first three lines on my little piece of paper for my notes are that. If we would only def- would define goals, we would have no disagreement. I am sure that your goals and our goals are identical. We want to produce the best possible kind of child equipped to deal with the complex society in which he will be asked to, to be. And the only place we disagree and here I feel we will disagree quite fundamentally because of things that I have to say are very basic. We disagree--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: As I'm sure the Montessori advocates would say, too--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, yes, I'm sure that I'm not at all sure that we're going to agree at the end of the program.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Well let's, let's let, let, let that be determined by the audience--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Alright. No, my point is this--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Goals, you spoke of goals--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Goals we agree on--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Alright--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: The, the way we- The way we achieve them--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: The m- Okay then suppose we ask--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: The way we achieve the goals that we are- that we are looking for. I think is what our difference would be, and I think if we try to set up what are our goals and then--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Okay--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Give some examples.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Well Hannah, Hannah MacLaren who I know follows the Montessori technique at the Ancona school. What would you say as a teacher your experience, the goals are or the credo of Montessori?
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I believe it, it is in probably three areas. The first one we consider would be self-development of the child. An awareness of the self of, of his ability to handle himself in situations, ability to maintain responsibility for himself, for others. This awareness in, of the child in- on this area also is particularly in the program which we develop is this perception of sense. The acuity of the senses, the basis on which a child can evaluate clearly, can find and develop precepts which later lead onto more abstract concepts of thinking, and then I think thirdly the initiative that is developed in a child. So that the child is truly spontaneous, and I think it should be. I would go one step further in, in terms of saying the kind of child that we would want to develop would want. Yes, who could live fully in the society, but who could also work within the society and create and begin to be the person who will seek the solutions for some of these so far insurmountable problems--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Social problems.
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Dr. Littner, listening to Hannah explain the goals, I'm sure that you yourself find nothing to disagree with in these goals, or do you?
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: No, I think that as Mrs. Bauling said earlier, there probably is a fair degree of agreement on goals. There are other aspects, though, that perhaps I think there is a fundamental disagreement. Studs, I thought that perhaps what I might do to introduce my own remarks is to raise some of my own questions and try and summarize my own concerns and put it all on the table right here.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Alright.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I think that everyone probably is quite agreed that Maria Montessori was a brilliant woman far in advance of many others of her days, particularly in recognizing the crucial importance of the first six years of a child's life. And that I would say just as Dr. Fleege said earlier, there is no question that we are all interested in trying to help children. But as I read the things that she and her followers have written, and I've been doing quite a bit of reading on it lately. And as I listen to some of their speeches, I am struck by some issues which to my mind are very fundamental issues and which raise the possibility in my mind that the entire Montessori movement is built on a theoretical quicksand. Now I have three questions, two concerns, which relate to these fundamental issues. The first question is a general one, and it has to do with the issue of arrogance. So many of the Montessori goals for children are goals that all of us are agreeing on and believing in. And yet it is with great dismay that as I read the Montessori literature the message it at least keeps coming across to me is that somehow these goals seem to be the exclusive possession of the Montessori movement. For example, we are told repeatedly that Maria Montessori said, "Never let a child risk failure until he has a reasonable chance of success." But somehow the statement, frequently in my readings, comes through with the implication that she invented the principle, that it's being copyrighted by the Montessori schools and it's only used by Montessori teachers. Almost as though the average parent really hasn't heard about it, the average teacher is too stupid to use it, and I, I would raise this as the first question.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Well, perhaps, hold up, and perhaps--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, I--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Can we talk to this, can we talk to this a bit--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Let, let me, let me--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Sure--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I'd rather if I may--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Oh all three you mean--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Go to the others and then we can come back because I--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: To--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I would like to put on the table--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Oh the whole summary--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: My, my own questions about this--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Alright, so Hannah and Urban, keep that first one in mind.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: The other- Another question that I would raise is what I call for lack of a better expression, and with a tip of the hat in the direction of George Orwell: double talk. As an analyst who's worked with children for te- for a long time, I agree wholeheartedly, Mrs. Bauling agrees, I'm certain with many of the Montessori goals. But as I study some of the basic principles and techniques advanced for achieving this goals time and time again, I am impressed by the fact that the Montessori methods actually employed in reaching the goals probably will produce children with characteristics that are exactly opposite to the goals mentioned. For example, let's look at the issue of creativity. The Montessori schools attempt to encourage creativity in the child, as I understand it, by giving him specific predetermined jobs to do and then allowing him to discover at his own pace with a teacher's help when indicated how to accomplish these jobs. I would imagine that he developed a great deal of initiative in learning how to solve these problems, but as I understand creativity, this is not creativity. But a- the exact opposite. Because I don't think that this kind of a method is the way one would try and produce leaders, that I would think this is the way one tries to produce ingenious followers. That as long as someone is around to tell them what to do. The overall task, they undoubtedly follow orders remarkably well. But I think to take a physical similarity, it's a little like a computer. You first program the child, and then you have to push the button. So engine- ingenuity. This is a que- This is a word I think is very applicable. Creativity? No. And in fact when you combine this particularly, particular Montessori technique of the structured environment with another Montessori principle, which has to do with not allowing the child to freely fantasy. I gather that if he starts to fantasy while doing one task one tries to divert him by giving him another task. Then it seems to me that what has been discovered is a particularly effective method for killing the child's spark of spontaneity, originality and true creativity. And this would be a second question. Let me go on to a third question. And this concerns the emotional impact of the Montessori method--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Dr. Littner, I, I, I'm just curious 'cause I know this is has a great deal of ammunition here for discussion debate. Is the third one- How many do have, just curious, 'cause I'm thinking about the round table--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Three questions, two concerns--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Are- This is the third one--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: This is the third question, and it's the emotional impact of the Montessori method on the child. Speaking as a psychoanalyst, it's my impression that some of the children exposed to the Montessori method, probably will tend to show delayed action, emotional damage in later years. And that this is because of a basic ignoring of the complex emotional needs of the preschool child. And I think that this emotional damage, if and when it occurs will come from three sources. That the first source is a tendency to emotional isolation of the child, which seems to me to be a built in part of the teaching method in the Montessori school. I gather that in most schools, the teacher-child relationship is considered the basic teaching school- teaching tool that is in the child development school. But I also gathered that in the Montessori School, this is not so, and that the Montessori child is programmed and conditioned to relate to the work items rather than to the teacher. This, I think, would be one source of this delayed action, emotional damage. A second source, it- of it if it comes would come from the interference by the Montessori method with the Montessori mother's- Montessori child's relationship with his own mother. As I see it, this interference result, results in part from the Montessori schools attempts to take away from the mother functions that really belong to her such as teaching cleanliness to a three-year-old. And in part, I think, the interference by the Montessori School in the mother-child relationship results from its attempts to program and automate aspects of the mother-child relationship right in the child's home. The very essence, I think, of a healthy mother-child relationship is a spontaneous emotional interchange in give and take between them. But the Montessori suggestions for home management of a child that I have read, tend to mechanize this relationship and to destroy its spontaneity. I'll stop after this third source. I think that there is a third source for what I would consider a potential delayed action, emotional damage, and that's the straight jacket that I think the Montessori method tends to impose on the child and his emotions. The three-year-old Montessori child finds himself in an environment that as far as I read is basically interested in conformity and order and preciseness and exactness and silence and politeness and composure and in obedience. All of which are very fine characteristics, but to apply them wholesale for all comers. I think in an, in effect straightjackets some of the more vulnerable children, and I would predict that some of these vulnerable children. The only way they are able to get along is to program themselves by a pathological inhibition of their emotions, because I see and a lot of psychiatrists sees these very overly polite and overly compliant little ladies and gentlemen all the time. And we call them obsessive-compulsive kids, and we have quite a difficulty of trying to help them. Now I, I'm talking too long at this point. I'll, I'll just put these three questions on the table, and I'll come back to my concerns later--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: And then Dr. Littner's raised--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Fine, I'll be very happy, Studs--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Urban Fleege--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes. If what Dr. Littner presumes is the Montessori program, and evidently he presumes it because in every case he said it probably will produce children exactly the opposite of what the goals aim to achieve. [clears throat] Excuse me, he says, it probably will create a delayed emotional reaction. If we could agree with Dr. Littner's assumptions, I would have to say, Dr. Littner, you are so correct. I agree with you. Unfortunately, what Dr. Littner has just done is built a wonderful straw man which any of us could knock down. But unfortunately it doesn't agree with the facts. And I would like to ask Dr. Littner, how much time have you spent in a Montessori school observing these children, so that you then might have some grounds for saying, it probably wouldn't? But you've tested them, and this is what happens. How much time have you spent for example in observing Montessori children in the school? Here--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I haven't spent any time, Dr. Fleege, because as I mentioned at the beginning of the program, my comments are based on the study of the writings of Maria Montessori and her followers and on listening to several of Montessori speakers including yourself. Mrs. Bauling has carefully observed functioning in the schools and will be able to report on her own concerns.
blocks.speaker: Ner Littner

blocks.text: We did try--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Though to visit, and we couldn't.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: I, pardon me--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Well that--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: What I think it might be a good ground, good--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I would like to--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: [But maybe I just missed?]--
blocks.speaker: Ner Littner

blocks.text: Comment on some of these--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Right--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: It seems to me though that Dr. Fleege is avoiding the main issue, 'cause the issue is not how many hours I have spent in observing Montessori children. I think the question really is how accurate and how safe is a Montessori system and its theories. And I am suggesting as I guess is rather clear that some of these theories are pure hogwash, that some of them may result in a delayed action, emotional damage to some of the Montessori children. And I think there are some other problems to which I'll come to--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Yes, if we could as--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I think perhaps these three basic points Dr.--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, and we will touch them but I say they represent an excellent straw man which we find no difficulty in. If we could assume that these things are correct, then these consequences would be the result. Number one [clears throat] the statement is made that Montessori seems to be rather arrogant, and that in reading her books she gives impression that she invented some of these-
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: She--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Her followers--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Her followers--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Or her followers--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Not she, her followers--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes. Well, of course, now whenever you take anything out of context or out of the time in which it was written, if you took Dewey for example in his earlier writings without realizing what the pattern at that time was, you could not fully understand correctly what he's trying to say. And I would suggest that the same is true in the inference that you have drawn that she is arrogant. In fact, she has stated that anything that I am saying if you have read all of her writings you will have come across this statement, I am not inventing anything new, but she was a wide reader. She was a tremendously interested in the work as a clinical psychologist in the work that was going on in Vienna with Freud, and consequently, this is one reason why she was so far ahead of her time. Psychoanalysis at the time she was writing was really hardly known and--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: That was a long time ago--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Neither was the recognition of the importance of what's happening to the child emotionally. Now that this has come to be acceptable, we are finding people fight, going back to her studies and finding in them, the very same things that I think Dr. Littner apparently does not see in the- but which does exist. So without doubt, she could not I don't think be accused of arrogance, except that she said--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I really didn't, Dr. Fleege, I said the writings of some of the followers--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: I think, not completely, if--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: He said the followers--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Hannah--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: One, one of, one of the, one of the problems--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I think this, this does happen very often, and it's- I think one of the flaws of any kind of new movement. But we've run into for instance as a teacher. People come and observe my classrooms, and especially this summer I had a large number and there was one teacher who said yes we have this and this and this. And I said that's wonderful. That is really fine, because I think for most of us in Montessori, we really aren't concerned that the name Montessori sticks. It's, it's that this gets to every child, and the form gets to every child, and so the exclusive label. The patent, the copyright is really not what we're interested in--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: I think--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: You know, any, anybody can take it.
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: I think, Hannah--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: This, this is fine--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Pardon me, I think Hannah may have a point here that could be the jumping off spot for the further discussion. I, I really do think that points two and three that were raised by Dr. Littner of the ones to be faced--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Hannah, and I think Urban agree. and Fay--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Could I say a little--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Bit about things that actually happen in the classroom--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Because I agree with you that when I first became upset about this. The reason I became upset, upset was because the thing sounded so good on paper, and the things that I had read, even reading the things sounded so good. And I thought well I'm going to see if it's true. And when I visited, and I found that by my definition this was not creativity. When I saw the kinds of things that children wanted to do and were prevented from doing when from my own knowledge of the things that children require in order to develop normally. These things were not available to them in a Montessori classroom--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes, may I interrupt a minute, Fay, now I--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This is the part that I heard on a previous program--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes, yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: And you cited something where the teacher interfered. All I can say is, she violated Montessori theory and nine times out of 10. I don't know how many times you visited the school, if you visited only once or twice--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: No, I--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: I think it is rather unfair to draw a general appraisal from such inadequate sampling of what's going on--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Then suppose, yeah, suppose--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: But fortunately the principle is that if a child is interested in doing something. Now we do not happen to have angels teaching--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: No--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: There are human beings. They make mistakes. And at our weekly conferences--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: We constantly are uncovering, because of our supervisors, and they realize that. But they forgot, or they lost--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Well then may, may I ask since, since what I'm particularly concerned with I have seen. And people I [who I?] whose opinion I can trust actually witness several procedures which I think are in your goals--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Suppose we, suppose we take a specific one--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: The pink tower. Let's talk about the pink tower--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Let's take a sip of things and then [unintelligible]--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, fine--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I've got a great example of this. Because the pink tower which should be put together in a specific way. Correct? It's presented--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: What is it--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Well, no, no, no wait a minute--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: It's presented, alright--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: It should be utilized in a specific way--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: It is presented to the child. The teacher shows the child how to do the buil--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Shows one beginning way to do it--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Right--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: How to build the pink tower--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: That's at the beginning--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Right, right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This is the beginning--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Alright. I- One of the things that I know actually that happened in our last discussion. Mrs. Chevalier told about how two children to- were together on the morning of the Glenn- John Glenn's space flight, and they were discussing the space flight, and this discussion led to a wonderfully free discussion among all the children of gravity and space and the kinds of things which you ordinarily do not consider in the curriculum, in a preschool curriculum. In the Montessori classroom on that same morning two little boys were using the pink tower, and they were pretending that this was the spaceship. The teacher came in and said that is not the way you use the pink tower. She took the children away was show- told them how to use it exactly. And the result was that this wonderfully marvelous creative conversation was cut off. The two children left the thing, and they did not return to it. I have seen this kind of thing--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes, may I comment on that, Fay--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: It's not just one time, Dr. Fleege.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Urban and then Hannah.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, I would say Fay that this- I don't deny that you may have seen this, or it could have happened even a couple of times. But what I'm saying is the principle that is involved is that spontaneous activity and to capitalize on the interest and the needs of the children. Now I have seen time and time again for example the number rise. Now there is a way of working with these so that they get a number concept, but I have also seen children who will take this and imagine that this long thing with the wings of a plane, and you'd be making noises. And the teacher permitted this to go on. So I think this is a momentary judgment of a teacher as to whether or not this is what she should permit or not. But the principle that's involved is spontaneous activity capitalizing on the needs of a child. I do not say nor can any system say that every teacher every time will recognize the Montessori principles--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: You mean your goals that are stated that materials should be used in prescribed ways is not so--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This is true to achieve certain objectives--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: But then it is so--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: But there is a role, and now I'm going to come to Dr. Littner's thing about fantasizing--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Could we come to the spontaneous activity [unintelligible]--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Yes, right now--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Just a moment. No, no, if we could hear from Hannah. Hannah teaches at the Montessori School. This pink tower, the use of material is--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yeah, yeah--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Hannah, how do you face this--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Well the, the, the thing- I think the implication, Mrs. Bauling, what you're saying is very misleading in that you presuppose that the only way a child can build is to put the largest on top of the smallest, et cetera all the way up--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: I don't presuppose--

Children should be introduced to the world of learning through a prepared environment in which specially designed apparatus and techniques are used to engage the child's mind at a given level of readiness in mastering a variety of tasks. And here for example is the Alcuin story. That's put up by you people. "A brief explanation of the Montessori apparatus, its meaning and purpose. Exercise, exercises of practical life, the exercises of practical life occupy a very important position in the Montessori education. Indeed, there are no more suitable exercises for a child of two and a half to five years of age. They are of paramount importance for complete and harmonious development of man physically mentally and morally. These exercises consist mainly of two groups those which have to do with the care of a child's own person. Those which are concerned with the care of the environment. The first group includes the following activities: dressing and undressing, combing one's own hair, brushing of teeth, washing ones's own hands and face, bathing, shoe shining, clothes cleaning, et cetera, et cetera. The second group includes such occupations as sweeping the floor or dusting, table washing, washing and ironing of, of clothes, arranging flowers, care of indoor plants, setting the table, serving at the table, dishwashing and numerous other household tasks depending on the civilization in which they are taking place. The lessons of grace and courtesy also belong to the exercises of practical life. They should be presented to the children in the same period of their development at the age of two and a half to five. This will include such matters as how to sit down and stand up properly, how to salute persons, how to beg pardon for small offenses, how to open and shut doors quietly, how to eat properly, et cetera. Furthermore, the development of balance and silence exercises are stimulated the exercises of practical life well done promote the coordination of movement, orderliness, diligence, independence, self-confidence, and good intersocial behavior. There is no better way of acquiring a good social behavior than these exercises carried out properly and enthusiastically in childhood. And this leads to emotional balance and stability." And I be- I have here, what I believe is--

Now you mentioned before that it does not allow the child to fantasize. All I can say is this is absolutely incorrect, and consequently since you state something that's incorrect. Your conclusion therefore is that this kills within the child the ability to, to be creative, and I would agree with you if this were true. It simply isn't now--

Studs asked her this question: Mary, what about fantasy that you, the Montessori people have been accused of not allowing the child to fantasize. And she said, as you have said, that it wasn't true and he said, could you give me an example of how it occurs in a Montessori classroom? And she said, well for instance when a child is working with the- with the matching of colors, I notice that the time when they begin to fantasize is when they know the material very well. And this little boy had completed the task of matching the colors, and he had done it over and over and over. So did that really belonged to him. He had conquered it, and at that point when it really- He felt that he was in complete control of the material, he got a kind of a dreamy look on his face and began to mix them up and use them in the way in which they were not designed to be used. And at that point, the alert teacher steps in and removes the material and gives him the next thing in the complication order for him to follow. Now at the point at which he is beginning to create is the point at which by her words the material was removed. This is what I call creativity.

blocks.text: I want to take as my text on this issue of fantasy. A quote from [Sid?] Harris that I read last time, how every child's mind is teeming with ideas. Too often these ideas are systematically throttled or strangled in the school system, which looks only for the right answers that aren't in the back of the book. What is in the back of the head is rarely encouraged to move to the front. I would like to read around this issue of fantasy, and how much fantasy these kids are allowed. Just a few lines from a book by Nancy McCormick Rambusch, founder and head mistress emeritus of the Whitby School, the president of the American Montessori society. She says, "in a Montessori class, there is a significant absence of so-called play material. This is due not to the absence of recognition that children work and play interchangeably, but due to the fact that Montessori recognized that a reality bound school situation may prove more beneficial to the child in order to his- to release his creative forces. At a time when he is incapable of distinguishing fact from fantasy," and in another part she says "in Montessori classes, there is an environmental emphasis on reality. While fairy tales and folk tales are pleasurable for children who are able to distinguish fact from fancy, they can be disturbing to children unable to make these distinctions. There are opportunities for expression of fantasy through writing and painting and free play in Montessori classes. These opportunities are less marked than those of many conventional nursery schools. Of course, they vary from culture to culture."

blocks.text: Exactly--

Which as Dr. Littner pointed out last time is his first problem at this stage. His first problem is not to, not to do the number work, and not to trace the A. His first problem is to--

The latest thinking in the child development world, a book that it was put out by the people who had an experimental lab school in Los Angeles, California, and these are the things which we have- feel are important in 1964. Based on a contributions from Montessori, from Piaget, from Froebel, from Pestalozzi. We are using them all. Now this statement I- is my primary quarrel with you. He learns through play to do the everyday things of life, trying on the adult world so to speak as he imitates what he sees and hears. This is a child's way of learning. You say that a child's way of learning is through work. I say that it's a child--

blocks.text: Not exclusively--

blocks.text: Who are in somewhat the same stage of learning as he is. Through group play with his age mate- he- mates, he learns many lessons in adjusting to the demands of others. Self-reliance and the ability to get along in the world we live in are developed through early group play.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: We have no--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: When we put up--

blocks.text: Our hands it's not because we want to [unintelligible] the room--

blocks.text: Alright Dr., Dr. Littner and then Dr. Fleege.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I want to register the strongest possible disagreement with the notion that the way one helps a child distinguish fantasy from reality is by squashing the fantasy before it has a chance to come out by showing him what reality is. I think that most people who have studied children say that the child, if he is to learn the difference. Must bring out his fantasies, must have a chance to experiment with them to discover what is realistic and unrealistic, and only in that way within the context of a relationship with a nursery school teacher, whom he admires. Only in that way will he ever pin down what is unrealistic and realistic. To not allow this to come out, but to present him with the reality is going to cause him to keep his fantasy in. And, if you want to make business for psychiatrists well, I, I have a mixed opinion here, but that is not the way the child learns to distinguish fantasy from reality--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Dr. Fleege--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: All I can say, Dr. Littner, is that there is considerable amount of research, which is going on now because of what Freud did and emphasized. This matter of the emotions, this matter of fantasy play and so on. And it seems to me that they are getting closer and closer to the recognition of Montessori, you see. The- I'm afraid but you're trying to do is get Montessori jockeyed into a position that's opposite of what you hold. The thing is if you read Montessori, you find out that she would not make this statement. Now, Fay, you just said your main bone of contention was--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This matter of play. The fact is, you see, Montessori does not say that a child can't learn through group activity, that a child doesn't learn through play. Recognized he does, except she goes one step further, and this is what we feel is experimental about the Montessori approach. It is not limited mainly to nursery- the so-called nursery school, which emphasizes play, but in addition that plus--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Well this is exactly--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: The structured activities--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Could, could we--

blocks.text: You say that it is not--

blocks.text: This plus--

blocks.text: Fay, I--

They're part of the public school system, and they have introduced to us, which is very revealing, dolls and a play, play corner area. And being you know having been trained in the grand tradition of American Montessori, I was, you know, slightly skeptical of this. And we found much to our surprise that the children don't use them.
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Oh.

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: And when they have a choice of these activities. So I would say to you, as Montessori expands, as we, as we become more sure of ourselves. That, that these things are being introduced, and our results are really being upheld, because of this--

blocks.text: May I say something about this play--

blocks.text: Around this issue of play, I think we have to be fairly certain of what are the facts. It seems to me that Mrs. Bauling and I are trying to present what the Montessori people are writing. This is from a paper presented at the National Catholic Education Association convention in 1961 by the same Nancy McCormick Rambusch, and she says "if children are to develop attitudes towards work and learning that are realistic forerunners of those they are expected to possess at the age of five or six. Society should demand that they stop playing and start learning."

blocks.text: Yes--

We have all that Holt Rinehart and Winston has. And if you know their programs, they are excellent books to prepare a child to read. This is there. You may not at that particular time when you visited have seen it. One of the things we feel- this is unique to--

blocks.text: Yeah, yeah--

We'd like to have you, but later. Now we have done the same thing. We didn't the first three years, but we found out that the teachers are getting these kids introduced, and some children have been here one day some others. And we feel that really you don't get a picture--

I think for the people listening to the program will undoubtedly replay this program several times. This next question I was about to come to the question that Dr. Littner just pointed out, you raised a third objection the beginning--

blocks.text: Yes, we have--

blocks.text: This is extremely important in terms of what it seems to me is automating- An attempt to automate the mother-child relationship. Let me just bring out, I am now reading again from Nancy Rambusch's book. "How the mother may help the child learn how to wash his hands. In preparing for the handwashing, the pitcher is filled with tepid water by the mother. She then kneels or squats to demonstrate with the child standing at her right or left depending on his hand- handedness, which we assume the mother knows. Obviously, there are many ways to wash hands. The point behind the structuring of this activity is to show the child a way that if done consistently always works and is satisfying to him. She would then do approximately the following: one, the mother pours the water into the basin about half filling it. In so doing she is careful to stop just at the moment of pouring after having tipped the pitcher in order to better control the flow of water. Two, she sets the pitcher down in the place from which she took it. Three, she places her hands in the water together with palms down and then turns them over. She does this twice to ensure getting the hands thoroughly wet." Studs, I see you, you recognize the fact that there are 17 steps that are listed here, and that she then goes on to say, "There are any number of home activities which can be structured in this way by patient mothers." I would say by crazy mothers, if this is the way they try to bring up their children.

I might reach a child, and it's ineffective if I'm introducing it--

blocks.text: To answer Dr. Littner's statement that Montessori is mechanizing the mother-child relationship and destroying spontaneity. One of the central planks in the Montessori approach to the child, and incidentally the first one who was a child development school, the first one who emphasized the child development approach was Montessori herself. So, the essence of the child development school is really the Montessori approach. Now--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: One part--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: One of the central planks is to recognize the individual differences in a child, and secondly that he is a spontaneous learner. He loves to learn by himself. Now the purpose of teaching mothers some of this is so that the child- You can, the mother can cut out the robbing the child of opportunities to become independent, of learning how to dress himself, how to wash himself, how to clean his face, how to feed himself--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: You know really, I think that this is the thing that upset me more than anything, was that--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: That word robbing--
blocks.speaker: Ner Littner

blocks.text: That you accused- I can say us when I talk about the child development school of being intellectual robbers, and I can only--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: To the extent--

blocks.text: I can only say that you--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: That you teach a child things, he can learn by himself--

blocks.text: Now--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: No--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Just wait--

blocks.text: Right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Now every child has certain basic drives. The need to achieve, the need to be doing something, the need to feel worthwhile, the need to be secure. Now, when he can do things by himself, he just thrills inside. He blossoms--

blocks.text: That's right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Emotionally. But if he does not, if he's not given the individual skills with which to enjoy these inner emotional satisfactions--

blocks.text: Why can't he try it the way he can--

blocks.text: Constant- He is--

blocks.text: He is--

blocks.text: Alright, Dr.--

blocks.text: Dr. Fleege--

blocks.text: Could I just say something. One of the things that disturbed me the most about reading the Montessori literature was the implicit depreciation of the mother that runs through much of the material. For example, this is a book called Montessori in the Home. The present pamphlet, it says, no, parents have been criticized for trying to make the most fruitful. These extremely important early years such terms as pushiness, pressure, over intellectual stress have been hurled at parents. Unfortunately, in many cases this is rightly so. For example, when thinking about the environment, and this is a quote, in which a child thrives of more importance than toy shelves, closet pigs, or small chairs, there's an atmosphere of calmness and quiet. The child should be sheltered from the hustling world, the bustling mother, and these little cracks that the mother there is always taking for granted. This poor, stupid woman, she really doesn't know how to take care of her kids. We're gonna have to help her, and I think that's one of the reasons why they list 17 steps for the mother to help her help her child wash his hands--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: And that's another thing--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: No, no more--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Hannah, Hannah, Hannah--

blocks.text: Hannah, and then Dr. Fleege--

blocks.text: That's right--

blocks.text: The, the implication isn't there, but that a lot of parents are confronted with- you know, what do I do in a situation--

blocks.text: That's right--

blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: That's right--

blocks.text: Now, I respond. Now, I see why my child was upset when such and such happened. And give us countless demonstrations on this--

blocks.text: Or orders--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes, I was just going to say, there are dozens--

blocks.text: This element of well- this well-behaved polite child, I'm sure this is part of this.

blocks.text: Of books on the market and apparently in great demand on the part of parents, who want to know more about their children. And how can they be a more effective mother? How, for example, can they deal with a child, so that he does become more independent, and so they are read. So now this book here, apparently, was written in answer to a request. How can I apply some of these insights within the home? I in four years have never heard, and I've been at dozens of parent conferences in which a directress went through 17 steps and advocated that the parents do the same. I have never. Now the fact is the directress [unintelligible]--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: The book is written for certain [unintelligible] to parents--

I don't think they advocate that the parents then go through all these steps, but if the parent understands, and the child is having a difficulty at a given level. The parent might be able to help--

That the implication is that a Montessori nursery school will really and truly help the child to learn quicker, to learn better, to do better in school, and that if you don't enroll your child in Montessori school, you're depriving the child--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: No--

blocks.text: In some way. Well I'm saying- I'm trying to say the way it comes across. I mean, I think that your- this is the way you're selling it, and I think if you want to sell it, it's a good way. I'm just questioning the validity of this, and I just think that it's, it's unfair. It's cruel to exploit the normal anxiety feelings that most parents have. They think this is going to be an answer, it isn't going to be an answer. It isn't an answer, because they--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: On what research now have you been able to draw that conclusion? This is a supposition on your part you see--

blocks.text: On, on the supposition--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: That probably this won't be [unintelligible]--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: No, no--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Give, give stay specific, because I- I would really- I, you know, I would--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Alright, I'll give you--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Say the same concern, but I don't think it's true--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Alright, I'll give you a specific--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: I think you're reading it into it--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: No, I'm not reading it into it. I am seeing the fact that there is not opportunity for children to explore at their level. Now one of the things I think--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: No, wait a minute, I want you to go back and answer--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: The comment about the parent anxieties--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yes, what about that--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Well, no. I mean, this is the statement you just said, and I- the, the material being sold--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: You mean like, if you have a choice between sending your child to university or sending him--
blocks.speaker: Ner Littner

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: To a Montessori school, send him to--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: That's right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: The Montessori school--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: That's a statement that's made, if you have a choice--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes, there are some people who feel--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Well, this isn't your own- I think that's a really terrible thing to say--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: That yes- I- Let me say, let me tell you, my convictions--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: As one who has been in education and child development at- From the very beginning, all the way up through graduate school, I am quite disappointed with the proportion of people who come to university, who have a sincere curiosity and love for learning. Who have a positive attitude toward it, and one goes back and then you find out, they had a record all the way down. They never became good readers. They had a hatred for mathematics and so on. So, it is my conviction now, that part of this goes back to a unfortunate introduction to the child- of the child to formal learning. Therefore, I believe, and this is why we think this is an experiment--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: So that others might come and take a look see and study it. That if we could- So introduce these children, so that these inner satisfactions from their initial contexts develop, then they will have this curiosity about them. Some of their keenest enjoyments have been associated with learning--
blocks.speaker: Urban Fleege

blocks.text: You know I--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Not all, but some--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: You know I might be--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: And a positive attitude--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Then if they can get the right start--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: If we can help them build within themselves--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I think this--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This foundation--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I think that's my real quarrel--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This then goes on up, you see--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes because you--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: But if they get an anti-attitude--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: That's right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: A hatred for school--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: That's right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: They're forced to go to school--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Because they have to, the parents make--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: That's right--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This I think is most unfortunate--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I think this is- I really my chief thing that I quarrel with you is because I don't think that at the age of two years and nine months that the way to build reading readiness is not talking. I think that--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: [laughs] My dear Fay--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Oh--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Just a minute--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: They talk constantly! They're beautiful when they talk--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yeah, but there--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: The things they say--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: But oral, oral communication is not given the place of honor, and the place of importance as it is in a child development nursery school. Because I don't see how you can have that much verbal communication, if you are so hung up on silence--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Well no, look, lookit no, oh--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: I don't see how you can--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: How much of a day do you think, Fay, is spent over to the silence game or of a week? Let's put it that way--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Well, you know, I think the most wonderful thing--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Well, no, answer my question. How much--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I dont know, but I'll tell you this--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Do you think? Well if you don't know--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Now just a minute, just a minute--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Then you see, you're drawing a conclusion--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: You offered me--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: That isn't verified--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Okay, you offered- you offered me an invitation at the beginning of this program to come and observe.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Yes.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: This- if nothing else comes of this program, if it will give me an opportunity to freely have open conversations and discussions with you on this. If we can really throw this thing wide open--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Absolutely--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I would feel, Studs, that you have done a fabulous thing--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Can--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: And I intend to pursue this--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: And, of course, you are doing it--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, can I pick up one other aspect--
blocks.speaker: Ner Littner

blocks.text: You were invited about a year ago to the--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: And I'm gonna take you up on that--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: We want you to--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Fine--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: This is why we welcome this opportunity--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: By the way I, if we can just make this parenthetical comment- We'll hear from Hannah, from Dr. Fleege and Dr. Littner, and- and Fay again. I think that the purpose of this roundtable is not so much a meeting of the minds as an airing of the differences of approach. Clearly, the goals are the same--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: With clarification--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Obviously, the goals are the same for the fulfilled, for the child to become a fulfilled human being. But there apparently is a difference as to the technique as to the approach. And this is the purpose of this particular roundtable. And obviously there will be no solution there's not to be any meeting of the minds of this afternoon. Let's call this a coexistence get together during the summit meeting, see. But at the same time, it's primarily designed for the listeners themselves to debate--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, yes, yes--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: And discuss these questions and to, to investigate it further. Now then, with that out of the way--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, I would like to come back to the--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Dr. Fleege--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Emotional thing, you see, actually, the whole program is designed for an emotional- a healthy emotional outlet of the child. Now, I think the average adult can understand what we're talking about here when they realize that if your emotions are bottled up, if you're not succeeding, if you're constantly frustrated, this isn't a healthy situation. Now, if you can, however, confront the child with those activities that answer deep needs within him, then this emotional enrichment. Letting out the emotion, and I don't understand Dr. Littner at all when he says about a delayed emotional reaction. This is reading into it that it is an imposed thing. It is not. It is disposing the child to do this at his level. A second point, Dr. Littner seems to object to some of the literature that's written in which they outline a specific way of teaching a child a given thing. In my experience as a teacher and as a teacher of teachers, one of the things we make is- at- the difference between an effective teacher and an ineffective one is principally in this area. The ineffective teacher surrounds the child with a confused approach, and they are guessing at what has to be done. The effective teacher is so clear that she has analyzed exactly what she's trying to put across, presents it one step at a time so the child can grasp it. This is what is one of the strong points of the Montessori approach in introducing the children to the various things that--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: No--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: We think they might learn. It's the specificity. One thing at a time, not confusing about clarity--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Simplicity--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: At the child's level of readiness, at the pace in which he can take it, and then if you go into a Montessori class, you don't see a teacher's desk. You don't see--
blocks.speaker: Urban Fleege

blocks.text: You don't see one in the child development school either--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: A whole group doing a thing. You see, you see all of these individuals working at their own level which is really the implementation of child development theory. For many years one of the things that confused me and sort of frustrated me in training primary school teachers and others was that we talked wonderfully about individual differences about the necessity of individualization of instruction, and then I would go out a few years later and see these people in the classrooms. And they just violated them right and left--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes, of course--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: And, it is my experience, and this is why I'm rather excited about this experiment. You go in there and really the best theory in learning theory and child development is being implemented--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Though I would--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Above all individualization of instruction--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Well, I would disagree. For one thing, if you have 18 children and two teachers and the two children are being, are being served many, many children in a Montessori classroom are sitting around and waiting--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Oh no--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: No, they arent--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Fay, this is not the case--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: They're--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Okay, okay, I would be so delighted--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: I want you to come--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: To be proved, to be wrong--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Please because this will--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: But I would like to say here, there's one thing that really gets me is this business about the, the children at their own level. When two children have an altercation, Hannah, may I ask you do you have a principle where that you try to let them work it out? Seems to me, I see this going through your material that you do not interfere too quickly. That if the children can work it out on their own, you feel this is better for their developments of self-reliance.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Unless someone's hitting the other one over the head with it [laughs]--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: It, it, it you know you feel it with a situation, yes--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yes, yes. Well, I have seen many times where there is an altercation, and the way the situation is resolved is that the stronger child wins out. The weaker child withdraws, sucks his thumb, quietly cries, does not go to the teacher for help, because it- the child by this time knows that the teacher is not going to run over and help him. I did- I say this child--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Oh no, this look--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Is not learning--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Look, look at what I don't know what the teacher--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: This is so contrary to everything we've seen--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Was doing but, this, this is not- This doesn't go on all- I mean, you know, you- it might happen say once. If you're, if you're bogged down, and you cannot get away from a group activity with the children or with an activity where you're involved with one child. But as a teacher if I, if I was standing there, if I was free, if I was capable of going over- At some point, no matter if it maybe if I can't do it immediately five minutes later, as soon as I could--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yes, that's the trouble--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: I would go over and give the support to the child, or I would do it immediately. There are many instances, where for instance, a child in a, in a battle in my classroom what--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Whatever's happened. You find out what has happened, and just, you know, mete out justice--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: I have heard this adjudicated--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Alright--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: You know what, I think, with Dr. Littner here about to--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, he certainly is--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: If we could make this- I, no, I, I think that we have no--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: [unintelligible] say something--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: We, we, we're going to hear from each of you certainly--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Surely--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: But I think that we're never going to cover, obviously, we're not going to cover all the ground of difference and of agreement. But, I think what we have been doing is airing certain key anxieties on the part of those who challenge Montessori. Certain response by those who are Montessori advocates. I would suggest this as a sort of a, a last go round for now. You know, each one can state his piece, and then we'll probably call this chapter one. Let's say, of a position- I think this calls for other meetings, obviously--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Wonderful--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: So, where do we begin. Dr.-
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I think we're, we should hear from Dr. Littner now--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Dr. Littner--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Well, I wanted to mention my two concerns, 'cause we won't have a chance to go into them and then say one final word. The, the reason why I called the others questions is because the parents basically have to make the final decision as to what they want for their child, and if what they want for the child is what I see as an automated program child. Well, that's their responsibility. But the concerns that I have are in another area. One concern has to do with the implication that the culturally deprived child- The answer- It will do well, and that this is the answer for the culturally deprived child. And this to my mind is a, an unproven thing. And as a matter of fact, I would think the culturally deprived child, if the cause of the cultural deprivation is an emotional deprivation at home, the built in tendency to emotional isolation in the Montessori school will traumatize just such a child. That's one concern. The other has to do with the issue raised by Dr. Fleege which has to do with what happens to children later on and the issue of school dropouts. To listen to some Montessori speakers, the implication is given that these- if children went to a Montessori school, this would decrease the number of school dropouts. To my mind, this is the rankest nonsense, and it's a dangerous concept because in view of the great multi-determination of school dropouts and in view of the extreme gravity of this problem today, this kind of a magical gimmick, which I have not seen any evidence for at all is a dangerous concept. Well, those are the two concerns. The final thing that I would like to say at this time, Studs- Why are you looking so worried--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: No, I am not. I'm feeling quite- I'm just keeping out of it--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Okay--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: I, I- My own impression of the Montessori system is that it had a great deal of value in the late 1800s when Maria Montessori was reacting to the extreme rigidity of the day. To my mind, its use today is an anachronistic throwback and an attempt to answer very complex problems with gimmicky methods. I think we produce enough emotionally disturbed children as it is, and I would seriously question employing a technique which unwittingly, but still deliberately attempts to program a child emotionally and automate the mother-child relationship.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Dr. Fleege--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Yes, Studs. I am a bit disappointed in Dr. Littner's apparent- not preferring to listen to what we have had to say and to pointing out to him that the things he has written in advance of the program he continues to read without making his remarks relevant to the discussion. He has written a number of cliches like automated child and emotional isolation of the child and so on. And anachronistic throwback to the 1800s, and he would like to write Montessori off apparently as a gimmicky method. All I can say is, Dr. Littner, I am sure you could not write and say these things if you gave yourself the opportunity of knowing what you're talking about firsthand and visiting the school. And I extend a warm invitation to you to come out, spend a day, a week, whatever time is available, and we will certainly do our best to make you feel at home. But I want you--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Will you also rewrite the books, too--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: To look at it with an open mind. I don't think we have--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: We're more--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: To rewrite any books because- as to--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: [unintelligible]--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: The anachronistic throwbacks. What you're then saying is that men of great reputation at a number of great universities, who are writing the very latest books on child development and research. Take for example this recent review of child development research published by the Russell Sage Foundation this--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yes, I know that one--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Past year. Take the work that was done by Stephenson of the child development school up at Minnesota on child psych. And you can quote study after study after study, which says and which underscores as a result of research the validity, the adequacy, the appropriateness of the principles which the Montessori schools are aiming to implement. And this business about emotional isolation, Dr. Littner, we have just stressed the fact that the whole approach is to emphasize the opportunity of the child to have proper emotional outlet and to write this type of thing is simply blinding yourself to the facts as they operate in a Montessori school. I have one other remark and that is I would like to say one of the reasons why I'm so interested in this experimental approach using the- and testing and evaluating the effectiveness of the Montessori approach. In 1964 in- with the metropolitan child is in addition to the fact that the latest research underscores the validity of the Montessori approach. It is the fact that I am not quite satisfied with what the preschools, the nursery schools are doing. I think that many will agree. I think all of us perhaps around the table here agree that there is an increasing interest in the child of three, four, and five, and this is due to the fact that for the first time in history these children are the recipients of a cultural impact of so many different impressions via mass media, television and so on that they are ready for school really and to learn things outside the home before the schools are ready for them. Now this in no way, absolutely in no way undercuts the value of the mother. Not at all. The interest of M- those who are writing in Montessori about how it can be applied in the home is to help the mother become more truly a mother. Answer the child's emotional needs within the home, help develop in him initiative and confidence in himself, independence that he can do things by himself. I find in the nursery schools that I visited, and I've been doing this for a number of years. And I think they're doing a, a marvelous job--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Some of them--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: I think there- yes, I think some of them are nothing but babysitting establishments. I think that maybe they are over impressed with the life adjustment school that emphasize group activity and socialization of the child and neglected a programmed approach to help introduce the child at readiness levels at his own pace. This matter of becoming independent. This matter of learning number concepts. This matter of clarifying his PR- PRSPs through various activities that he gets a tremendous kick out of, to develop his sharpness of eye, ear, and so on. And it's the absence of these activities in the nursery school that I think is the plus factor in the Montessori approach.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: So--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Alright, my turn--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Fay Bauling--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Well, I would say that if I could pass a magic right now and somehow or other combine the best of both approaches, and maybe this is what Studs had in mind as a goal for the future. It would be simply wonderful. My chief quarrel is that when you say at the child's level we are not agreeing. You are spending a great deal of time developing small muscle coordination with your exercises with the rice pouring and all of these things so that the child's small muscle will develop earlier. Where I feel that the small muscle will develop earlier anyway. I would like to see more emphasis on what he has at this time and use that to the fullest. I don't think you have enough opportunity for large muscle development. I don't see the emphasis on outdoor play equipment that you need. I feel that there are basic things that a, that a child needs to learn that he can only learn through non-structured play material, which is absent from a Montessori classroom. And this is the reason that I am concerned, as I said in my initial call to Studs. I am not as concerned with what they are doing, as I am concerned with what they are not doing, and so I feel that the learning- the valuable things that you want them to learn. They can learn better, easily, with less emotional trauma in a school which does not have so many structured activities which has more fluidity and more opportunity for the child to be more natural and more naturally joyful.
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Hannah MacLaren.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: Well, I'm, I'm not going to answer that because I, I think it's just a matter of interpretation and how we see children in much of this. Except for the fact that we do have a tremendous amount of gross motor activity, which is this, which would be the opposite of the small--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Outdoor activity--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Outdoor activity--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Give me an example--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: A lot of--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Jungle gym--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Ner Littner

blocks.text: Walking- jungle gym, walking on the line. A lot is calisthenics--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Walking on the line. This I cant get over--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: A lot of large--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Why does he have to walk on the line? Excuse me--
blocks.speaker: Fay Bauling

blocks.text: Oh because they love it--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Coordination of activities--
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Have you ever watched a child walk down a street and not try and hit that crack? It's a great fascination to them--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: At what age--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Well, mine do it at three. I just happened, you know, I, I not- I assume soon as they become capable of, of just more than more mobilizing themselves--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Then they get into hop, skip, and jump.
blocks.speaker: Dr. Urban Fleege

blocks.text: Yeah--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Well, Hannah, I don't want us to sound too final--
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: No--
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: Because there's not the final word, but this is not famous last words, but let's say for the moment for this session. Hannah is winding up this particular- We've all had our turns and, Hannah, your, your credo, whatever you wish to say as a result of this.
blocks.speaker: Studs Terkel

blocks.text: I think especially at Montessori, especially at An- Ancona which I'm most involved with. That we don't have the final answer, and we don't pretend to. But I think that we feel that for us, for a beginning structure for a way of looking at the child for the results that within the Montessori framework which is, is a large part, but not the be all and the end all of a child development. That Montessori does provide the insights, the corollaries- That is as Dr. Fleege has said are substantiated by new and continuing research, and I think that, that this attitude should be kept very much in mind that when something is written down. It was written two years ago, that we should always be looking forward, and this is what's going on in, in, in our classroom. It's very important, and I think we come to the child with a very humble aspect. A very humble consideration of the child and work with the child within this framework, and for my own feelings, the results are very proven.
blocks.speaker: Hannah MacLaren

blocks.text: I think at the risk of repeating oneself, since obviously, I say this is a beginning and certainly not an end for this discussion.
